My current work focuses on using WiFi to enable precise and accurate (sub-meter) indoor localization for robots and people.  We believe this can offer tremendous opportunity for re-defining our indoor spaces.  Imagine a "Google search" of physical objects indoors or navigation indoors.

The focus of my dissertation work are problems related to communication for multi-agent systems.  In particular we study how to position mobile routers such that they can provide communication coverage for clients, where these clients can be vehicles, robots, or people.  Real world solutions for this problem requires realistic communication modelling, big data analysis for large networks, and application of optimization tools (both centralized and distributed) for achieving networks with desired performance guarantees.  Separately, I have worked in the areas of hybrid model learning, energy harvesting, and have been a part of several NASA projects including Solar Sails and the Mars Exploration Rovers.
Experience: Visiting the Stanford Robotics Lab directed by Oussama Khatib to explore coordination and manipulation tasks for the summer
Multi-robot coordination and control, algorithm development, studying the impact of communication on coordination for multi-robot tasks
Our mission is to achieve technology transfer from our lab at MIT to the healthcare setting with maximum impact.

I work at the intersection of robotics and wireless communications.  We are currently developing an indoor positioning system based on WiFi for accurate (sub-meter) localization inside of buildings such as hospitals.  I am interested in talking to healthcare professionals in the hospital setting to understand what the biggest challenges are around Real Time Location Systems (RTLS) in hospitals.

Education: Research within Machine Learning, Deep Learning, Natural Language Processing, with a focus on Discourse -- both from a wide-lens (Citation Prediction) and fine level of granularity (Coreference Resolution for entities and events).
Experience: I teach graduate courses in NLP, Machine Learning, and Data Science, and advise Master's and undergrad students on research. Classes: Deep Learning for NLP (58 students); Intro to Data Science (380 students); Advanced Data Science (280 students and includes CNNs, LSTMs, Transformers, GANs, RL, etc), Master's Research Capstone course (real-world team projects w/ industry partners)

Taught Introduction to Computation for Humanities and Social Sciences, a course which introduces non-Computer-Science students to computation via Python.  Created all course content, gave all lectures, held office hours, and managed 5 TAs. 27 students.

Researched and developed approaches for natural language understanding / slot-filling and intent classification. That is, given a transcription (e.g., “Play David Bowie by Phish”), correctly label each word as being an artist, track, album, etc, along with the overall intent of the speech.  My Bi-LSTM model showed significant performance gain over the original system.

Researched and developed deep learning approaches to IBM Watson question-answering. I implemented denoising autoencoders (traditional, stacked, and marginalized stacked) for pre-training, for the task of learning-to-rank candidate answers.

Working at the Human Language Technology Center of Excellence, I research and developed report-to-source linking (automatically finding relevant source documents/references for a given report/summary document).
